A clipper cutting guide for the babyliss E769E. This guide is a replacement for 3 to 18 mm.
The reference of the clipper is in europe E769E but it's name is Babyliss for men W-tech Titanium. Take care, the guide is fragile (as the original one !)

I printed the "sabot-3-18mm" with PLA at very low speed with support (everywhere in cura parameters). You can try to print it up or down, I was only able to print it up.  
Be very careful when removing the support as the guide breaks easily.  
Theres is a few (plenty :-) of errors in the modelling. The mesh are not merged as blender is not able to do it with version 2.6.  
Have a good cut !
P.S. I added two almost (not) corrected model. The stl files are peigne-12_fixed.stl and peigne-v0-fixedByNetfabb.stl

description.text:
This pair of parts test capabilities of a printer and the quality of the casting process. They are often plated in sets of 4-10 to test retraction on the printer before the casting process. They yield easily quantifiable data for whatever metals that can be cast.
Data sets are:
edge case cast-ability
hole size shrinkage
pillar [hole] integrity These were some of the parts used to gather data for the Rapid Manufacturing articles on Open3DP http://open3dp.me.washington.edu/2014/10/rapid-manufacturing-iteration-and-industry/

After Android Lollipop was announced, I decided I needed recreate the Android Lollipop statue. I ended up creating different hand pieces, which allows for printing different configurations (see instructions). Here's a quick video on how to assemble the pieces:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N0vYl_B-8Ng If you print one (or more), please share images!

For printing on my UM2, I print with default infill at 0.2mm height. Only the eyes are printed on 0.1mm height as that makes them a little smoother (and they are very small, so it still prints quickly). The head and body need support structure. The other parts print fine without. The body and hands should be printed upside down. You need to print the following:
  • 1x body
  • 1x head
  • 1x head ring
  • 1x set of eyes
  • 2x shoulder pin
  • 2x shoulder ring
  • 2x arm
  • 2x arm pin
  • 2x hand (any combination that you desire)
    • The hands come in different variants:
  • plain
  • fingers (hand with 2 fingers like the official lollipop statue)
  • 4.5mm hole (perfect for holding a Chupa Chups lollipop)
  • 5.5mm hole (for larger lollipops)
  • 4.5mm hole half way (for adding accessories to the robot)

description.text:
My friend owns an antique katana and he wanted to display it nicely on his wall in a sturdy, but minimalist pair of holders.  
So I created this two-piece holder involving a hidden mount that is screwed into the wall.  The main body of the holder slides over top of the mount, completely concealing the mount and the screws and giving a smooth look.  
The OpenScad file contains the code for generating the holder and mount, in case someone wants to tweak the dimensions or adapt for a different purpose.  It is made specifically to fit my friend's sheathed katana.    A variable in the file controls whether the holder or the mount object is created.

Both the left a right holders are identical.   So you just print each object twice.  
I painted the holder to give it a faux bronze appearance.

description.text:
Simple light made with one CR2032 battery and diode. Designed in 2 variants - with or without round cover. The light can be switched on/off by sliding the battery on the bottom.
No supports are required.
For more photos see my blog article (Polish) on 3dwpraktyce.pl.

Lights are designed to print without supports:
  • LedLight-simple.stl - without cover - simply print it the flat surface down.
  • LedLight-cover.stl - this one is a bit harder to print, but it is still possible to make it without support materials (if your printer can make a 2 cm bridge). Print it the battery slot down.

description.text:
We made this mount for 2,4,5 & 6 GoPro's to film a 360Âº Video Panorama. UPDATE: I just uploaded a 6 GoPro spherical mount. You need to print the following

description.text:
The Ajanta Caves (Aji??h? leni; Marathi: ?????? ????) in Aurangabad district of Maharashtra, India are about 30 rock-cut Buddhist cave monuments which date from the 2nd century BCE to about 480 or 650 CE.The caves include paintings and sculptures described by the government Archaeological Survey of India as "the finest surviving examples of Indian art, particularly painting",which are masterpieces of Buddhist religious art, with figures of the Buddha and depictions of the Jataka tales.The site is a protected monument in the care of the Archaeological Survey of India,and since 1983, the Ajanta Caves have been a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
To know more check below given link.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajanta_Caves

description.text: Mount Greylock (highest point in Massachusetts) - Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. This is using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. I hope to release the new software as soon as I get any kinks out.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

This leather children's shoe was likely made by an enslaved craftsman named "Old Jack" in 1862 for the Nolan family of Cleveland County, North Carolina. The shoe can be found in the North Carolina Museum of History's permanent collection. It is usually on display in the exhibit, "The Story of North Carolina."
You can find more information and added historical interpretation here: http://susannalee.org/dh/2014/11/02/a-shoe-and-the-historical-record/

The leather shoe was scanned by a MakerBot Digitizer 3D desktop scanner. The MakerBot Digitizer works by using two guiding lasers and a video camera to capture the details of the scanned object.  The object turns slowly on an automatic turntable, and multiple scans of the object can be combined in the software to create a single, detailed scan.  First, the shoe was scanned as it lay flat on its sole.  Then, the shoe was turned to sit up on its heel and scanned again.  The combining of the two scans, rendered a relatively detailed 3D model of the shoe that showed interesting details of wear and tear and captured the intricately textured surface of both the top and the bottom of the shoe.

This is a nice thing if you want to reflect laser beams. I first saw this thing in a scanner a while back. I am using Libs.scad http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021 to make the spheres, its really slow so uploaded .stls ready for printing. So referring to the picture, its only the thing on the end, you use a M5 screw to put the ball, base and lid together. Just loosen a little and rotate the ball ... remember to glue a mirror on the ball.

description.text: Every time the same question. How to build two competitive teams out of all 'hobby' players that show up. If one does it by selection there is always someone who is guilty after the game if it fails. Better to draw the team players. But as paper snippets get lost over the time I prepared coins in different colors. Up to three teams can be found each 6 players maximum (it's for indoor cage ball). Good luck...

You can use almost any type of material but I choose 3mm birch plywood. Both sides of the coins are in one file. As first step cut and engrave the first side. When finished don't remove the remaining material but use it as a frame. Fix it with one hand and turn the coins in place. Then start to engrave the second side. To color you can use a marker or a color pen for wood.

title: Prusa I3 Printable Filaflex Flexy Feet

description.text:
Add these to your aluminium framed Prusa I3 to dampen some of the vibrations that are transmitted into the desk / table / floor / house.  
CornerFoot-3.0.stl has a 3mm thick base, CornerFoot-4.5.stl has a 4.5mm thick base.  I used 3mm at the front and 4.5mm at the back to support my Prusa I3.  
Freecad files included so you can set your own thickness.  Just change the depth of the first pocket.

Print using flexible filament (i.e. Filaflex).  I sliced using Craftware with 10% infill.  
Print 2x AluFrameFoot.stl and 4x CornerFoot-n.n.stl

remixed_from.title: The Openscad General Library of Relativity

title: String Theory, a string library for OpenSCAD

description.text:
This library is a spin off of Relativity, my other OpenSCAD library. I needed a string processing library for some more advanced features I wanted to implement, and since none were available to my liking I rolled my own with help from some earlier work by roipoussiere.
The library includes the following functions:
  • before(string, end)
  • after(string, start)
  • between(string, start, end)
  • substring(string, start, length)
  • upper(string)
  • lower(string)
  • is_empty(string)
  • is_null_or_empty(string)
  • is_null_or_whitespace(string)
  • equals(this, that, ignore_case=false)
  • starts_with(string, start, ignore_case=false)
  • ends_with(string, end, ignore_case=false)
  • reverse(string)
  • trim(string)
  • parse_int(string, base)
  • tokenize(string, index)
  • join(strings, delimiter)
  • split(string, seperator=" ", ignore_case = false)
  • index_of(string, goal, ignore_case=false, regex=false)
  • contains(string, substring, ignore_case=false, regex=false)
  • replace(string, replaced, replacement, ignore_case=false, regex=false)
  • grep(string, pattern)
  • peg(string, grammar)
    • All functions are compatible with the latest production release of OpenSCAD, 2015.03. No dev release needed. For those still using version 2014.03, you can still use the older version of the library by checking the project history on Github. Code shares its repository with relativity.scad: https://github.com/davidson16807/relativity.scad/blob/master/strings.scad 2/2/2015 That right woodchuck chuckers, it's Groundhog's Day. A new function has been added, called peg(). This function offers support for parsing expression grammars. Parsing expression grammars allow you to create your own mini programming languages within OpenSCAD. The engine is currently too slow to describe complex languages using Backus-Naur form, but for now you can specify grammars using an intermediate format that uses nested lists. Look to _rx_peg in the string.scad source code for an example grammar - this is the grammar used within strings.scad to describe regular expressions. You can also find some nacent documentation available here 3/17/2015 Happy Patty's Day. Thanks to new functionality in 2015.03, all string processing functions return a list of strings, where appropriate; e.g. grep() now returns a list of strings matching the input regex. 11/27/2014 Thanksgiving update. Regex now supports negative character sets ("[^aeiou]"), character ranges ("[a-z]"), and curly bracket repetition (".{2,3}"). 11/13/2014 Added regular expression engine. The engine supports all basic regex operators ("|", "*", "+", "?", "."), anchors ("^", "$"), character sets ( "[...]"), metacharacters ("d","s", "w"), parentheses, and operator precedence. Regex functionality is exposed where ever there is a "regex" parameter flag in a method's signature, and of course, through grep().

title: Bed level adjuster for Da Vinci printers (possibly other makes)

description.text:
Made these to make it easier to adjust the bed height on my Da Vinci printer as I was finding the stock thumb screws a bit awkward.
The handle on the end makes it easier to adjust and also provides a visual aid to help judge the amount of adjustment.
Just add an M3 nut on the top, mine are super glued in place
They may also work with other printers with 3mm bed levelling screws, I'd be greatful if you could leave a comment if they work with your make of printer. Use the short one at the front and 2 of the longer ones at the back.

description.text:
Here's my latest design, a 3D printed mini tricopter. I wanted an FPV racer, but also something that would stand out from the masses of other minis out there. It's either 250 or 280 size depending on the arms installed. Complete specs:
  • SunnySky 2204 2300kV motors
  • Gemfan 5x3 Props
  • Magic 12A ESCs with SimonK
  • Glacier 3S 1000mah Battery
  • Naze32 Flight Controller
  • HS-55 Tail Servo
  • PZ0420M FPV Camera
  • HobbyKing TS5823 Mini Video Transmitter
  • 6x M3x14mm screws for the body/arm connections
  • 2x M3x8mm screws for the battery cover
  • 1x M3x35mm screw, 2x M3 washers, and 1x M3 lock nut for the tail
    I sell kits for those without 3D printers, though I have a feeling that everyone on here would rather print one for themselves. Enjoy!

Recommended print settings:
  • Layer height: 0.2mm
  • Number of Perimeters: 2
  • Bottom Solid Layers: 3
  • Top Solid Layers: 3
  • Infill: 50% for the tail motor mount, 20% for everything else
    I usually print in PLA for better inter-layer adhesion and more rigidity, but ABS should be fine as well.

comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Not without tilt.  You have 2 motors going one direction and 1 motor going the other.  So you have twice the torque in one direction that you need to counteract with the tilt rotor on the back (technically any motor could be tilted).  With most multirotors you see motors in counter rotating pairs (even numbers of motors) but with a tri you have to counteract the torque with tilt.

comments.text: I have a transmitter for an RC plane from hobbyzone.  The transmitter is technically a 4 channel, but the plane is a 3 channel.  If I get a 4 channel receiver and the motors, ESC, props, servo, etc. , will that work?  Thnx a bunch.  :)
comments.author: billyd

comments.text: No not really. You need 4 channels for flight control, but then that leaves you no channels for switching modes and configuration of the flight controller.
comments.author: SajjadA

comments.text: A cheaper solution would ba a Flysky th9x also known as Turnigy 9x as well as other names, the great thing about this 50 to 80$ TX is, receivers are dead cheap, and you can upgrade it with openTX Firmware (same as on the taranis) and change the module later to a FrSky or UHF one. A bit more work then a Taranis, but less costs to beginn with and it can grow with you.
comments.author: billyd

comments.text: Of course. I had mentioned the costs can vary widely for any of this stuff. I have found that some of the super cheap stuff can be problematic, so I tend to stick to the middle tier. But there are so many choices and especially if you don't mind waiting for a China shipment you can go crazy cheap. The reason I mentioned the X9D is it's a radio that can last someone a lifetime in RC. At $200 it is relatively cheap given what the transmitter can do (similar capabilities in other radios can cost in excess of $1000) and you can get receivers for it for $20 as well. There is really nothing the X9D can't do, so you will almost never hit a wall with it, in terms of functionality.  But certainly your suggestions are more than adequate to fly this tricopter and plenty of other things. But if you are going to get into the hobby more seriously, I find it's best to go ahead and make the investment, rather than ending up with a dozen different cheaper radios.

comments.text: It's definitely a yaw controller tuning issue. Make sure the tail servo responds in the correct direction to resist yaw motions, then start working with the PID values. The defaults are probably a bit high, so try cutting the Yaw P term in half and then slowly increasing it until you get solid tail performance without oscillations.

comments.text: what is the purpose of servo?
comments.author: Kwoktony919

comments.text: The servo tilts the rear motor.  Without it the tri would spin like a top and could not yaw.  The servo is needed to yaw the tri as well as counteract the torque from the motors.  Quads and Hexs do not need a servo as they have an even number of motors and can have equal numbers of motors spinning in opposite directions to counteract the torque from the motors.  As a tri has an odd number of motors it cannot counteract the torque of the motors using opposing motors alone and must tilt one of the motors to provide vectored thrust.
comments.author: Kwoktony919

comments.text: You can run a tri either way since you have the tilt servo that can compensate.  However it will tilt less if you use 1 different prop.  I prefer for the front 2 props to always spin into the copter.  So looking at the tri from the top down with front pointed up I have a CW prop on the left and a CCW prop on the right.  Then just pick one of those two for the rear motor.  I currently use a CCW prop on the rear but you can use either.

comments.text: I believe CW is considered "normal".  Meaning that the nut tightens when you rotate it in a clockwise rotation...ie "righty tighty".  The motor itself has no predetermined rotation.  Brushless motors have 3 leads which don't have to be connected in a particular pattern.  Swapping any 2 leads will cause the rotation of the motor to reverse.

description.text: Ngorongoro Crater - Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 2.55 million facets). I know it's a giant file but, it looks great...can't wait to print it (well, look up above...I did!). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

The SkyHunter is a big plane...and I don't like taking mine apart. It needed to get off of my floor and up on my wall!
These mounts hole the Sky Hunter by the tail boom. Print 2 and use the tail as a guide for where to install them.
The version in the pictures isn't exactly like the one here. There have been 2 minor modifications:
  • Added a "path" for the elevator so it wouldn't hit the mount
  • Made the front of the mount parallel to the wall (purely cosmetic).

description.text:
My father asked if I could make a cup to hold a single pen or 2. He wanted it weighted and conical. When I whipped this up for him, he said "That's just like the one I had on my drafting table in the 70's!".
Bottom of cup is open to take a 51mm OD, 21mm ID, 3mm thick washer. It's probably imperial sized, but I didn't bother measuring.

Printed using 20% infill for a little more mass. ABS at 0.3mm layers.
Had to print with supports for the Washer hole, which means my slicer had to add supports to the inside of the cup. If you can stop the slicer from adding supports after a certain layer or overhang, do so, the cone of the cup should print fine without.
Sanded the opening a bit to get the washer to fit. Few drops of CA glue to hold.
Applied an adhesive rubber bottom for grip and appearance.

UPDATE 2/12/17. This part was used in the Ghostbusters Station 6 fan film. Check it out on youtube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RHMUsQqLmRg A 3D printable corner for the Ghostbusters proton pack motherboard
based on Steffan Otto's plans at:
http://www.gbfans.com/wiki/Stefan_Otto%27s_Prop_Plans As the plans are, this part seems to foul the HGA assembly which is above it. I've updated the gearbox bottom at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:509510
to raise the HGA slightly.

description.text: Simplified and effective way to hold third party filament spool for XYZ da vinci 3d Printer. I may work for other 3D printers as well. No more tangle filament.

Use double side tape for the saucer as it needs to stay foot. Put the spindle with female side face down and over the top of the male side of the saucer. It should spin freely even without ball-bearing. Place you filament on the very top. See picture. I have been using this design and it works great for me.

author: technutty

description.text: I just got frustrated with the fact that every spool is a different size and shape.  There are a few that attempt to be universal, but many of them are not printable on my simple.

At my local hardware store, I bought a few of the aluminum angle beams. Specifically, I used 5 at 3/4in x 36in.
Cut 3 of the beams into 1ft sections
Cut 2 of the beams into 18in sections.
Print 8 corners and 2 beam rests.
Assemble.
Use the holes in the pieces as guides to drill holes and screw together if desired for stability.

Bologna, chicken, pig, cow, and turkey as one. Concept thumbnails included of alternative designs. thought it might be fun to have a herd of them as all different sorts of varieties. After exploring concepts, I roughed the body in oil based clay, using a stick to keep it upright for the sculpting and scanning. After scanning I brought it into Z-brush for smoothing, detailing, decimating, and adding tail feathers. Last added base in Z-brush.

remixed_from.title: Universal car mount for Nokia lumia 520

description.text:
This car phone mount can be customized to accommodate a wide range of phones and cases. It clips onto the vent using the really nice vent clip designed by jasper_pues.  The concept was inspired by the gcode developed by diametric.  
Update Apr 20, 2015: Unfortunately I had to remove the rounded edges due to a problem with the customerizer.

Use the customizer to put in the dimensions of your phone or case.  The sized you put in will be the size of the space on the holder.  You should add one or two millimeters to the sizes you measure on your phone to make sure you can slide it in and out easily.  The vent clip is printed separately and should be glued into the slot once the prints are done.  A couple of drops of superglue works great.  The clip prints stronger if you lay it on it's side, if you do you'll need support, otherwise, no support should be needed.  You may need to clip off a string or two from the mounting slot depending on how well you printer does bridging.  Obviously, your printer will need to be well calibrated to print this the correct size.

title: Shelf support for bookshelves with 5mm holes

description.text: I created this to replace broken/missing shelf supports for bookshelves. They push into standard 5mm holes in the side of a bookcase. The  spigot is deliberately octagonal rather than circular for better printing, and so that they have some give when pushed into the 5mm holes.  The tab at the end is to allow them to be gripped with pliers to pull them out of the sides of the bookcase.

You may need to adjust the size of the spigot in the OpenScad module, so that when printed on your printer they fir 5mm holes well. Because they are small, I recommend printing at least 4 of them at a time, so that each layer has time to cool before the next layer is printed.

title: One-button adapter for Lifemax 1233 talking clock

description.text: The Lifemax 1233 talking clock is supposed to be suitable for visually-impaired people. Unfortunately, the design makes it anything but. The central button that you press to get it to tell the time is surrounded by five larger buttons to set the alarm, silence the alarm, set the time etc. So a partially-sighted person who doesn't have an extremely good sense of touch has very little chance of pressing the correct button, and every chance of making the clock do something else. I designed this cover to fit over the top of the clock and provide a single large button to get the clock to tell the time. The other buttons can be pressed by pushing a straightened-out paper clip through the holes provided, to allow someone else to adjust the time etc.

After printing the parts, put the large round part on the top of the cover (the side without the circular indentation) and secure it in place by pushing the small round piece on the other side, using a drop of superglue to hold the two round parts together if necessary. Then use double sided sticky tape to attach the cover to the top of the clock.

description.text: Clip your Medela baby bottles into this drill chuck attachment and spin the bottles in a bowl of hot tap water to warm them. Cuts warming time by 75% or so and doesn't froth the milk.

Print your part in ABS so the hot tap water doesn't soften it. After printing, trim off the support buttresses flush with the shaft. If you have the old style Medela bottle caps with four ridges on the sides, use the file labeled 'old'. If you have the new style with no ridges and a wavy skirt, use the file labeled 'new'. Optionally, for extra strength, install an m3 by 30mm long button head screw and nut through the shaft. Stainless is recommended. The parts are optimized for a 0.35 to 0.40 mm extrusion width and they fit in a 3/8" drill chuck.
To use, chuck your bottles into your drill, immerse in hot tap water, and spin clockwise/forward in 5 to 10 second bursts with equal pauses in between. Both the water and the milk/formula should spin up and spin down without frothing. For optimum warming speed, change out the water when it gets cooler or leave the hot water trickling into the bowl.
Alternatively, if you only have a slow electric screwdriver, you can spin the bottle continuously at low speed on its side or at an angle under trickling hot water or in a bowl of hot water.

description.text: This is a derivative of the Printruder II - Rear Breech Loading by juniortan and of course the original design by Zaggo. For some reason the derivative feature wasn't working properly :( ...So I made it a new thing. Here is the PNEMAtruder! The "P" is silent :D It has all the features of the junior tan's version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3178 the rear breach and gear access. It is a direct drive stepper extruder that uses a high torque NEMA 17 in order to drive filament to extrude. Or a high torque NEMA 23 Also, an optional filament tube clamp can be attached at the top, for those with filament spindles. This is still a work in progress, but I thought I'd put it out there for all to see and make suggestions, etc. The center has been changed so I can't use any existing support designs. What do you guys look for in your supports? low part counts? Easy to print? Function/Flatness? Maximum Z height? Would you want me to make laser cut supports for purchase/download? Does anyone actually read this and answer? So far, no so I'm just designing features I want. 1/12/11 I'm currently working on a revised version that axes the NEMA 17 and utilizes a NEMA 23. Most high torque NEMA 17's that I can find just don't have enough torque to get the job done. I uploaded a screenshot of the new design. None of the files are updated, yet. 6/4/11 With MBI selling the 100 in-oz NEMA 17 motor in there store you can now use the 17 design.

I haven't had a chance to see if it will even print and sadly I won't until the new year, since i'll be on vacation away from my bot :(
They're 2 flavors, one with a 625 bearing which will fit the NEMA shaft or one with a 626 bearing. The 626 is a cheaper bearing, but has a 6mm ID so you will have to use a nylon shaft adapter or build up a millimeter of tape on the shaft or I suppose you can print one if your bot is calibrated well and you have cooling fans.

comments.text: I think you're doing your torque calcs backwards.  As the moment of force moves away from the pivot, the required torque to move the arm INCREASES, it doesn't decrease.  The mass that a given torque (ie:motor) can move decreases as the diameter grows.  For instance, a motor that can move 1kg on a pulley 1cm from the center can only move 100g at a distance of 10cm (yet both of these measurements would be an identical torque of 1kg*cm).

description.text:
While attempting to assemble an Antenna Tracker, I was having trouble handling the servo's and needed something to prototype them with.
The result is a set of small "building blocks" that can be assembled with 3mm hardware.
If anyone finds these of use, great !
The antenna tracker can be found at :
https://github.com/KipK/Ghettostation

All of these were printed in PLA.
2 perimeters, 15% infill, 0.3mm layers
I started with printing support, but realized that i did not need it.
The holes are 4mm, but my printer & Slic3r make them a bit smaller. They should not have to be drilled for 3mm hardware use.

This is a simplistic design to fit the bill of a laptop cooling tray. Instead of having vents pull in from the bottom, it has them on the side so sitting the laptop on uneven surfaces does not obstruct the air flow. This also allows for the bottom to be completely flat and if constructed out of rubber or coated in plastid, it will not slide around on surfaces as other conventional trays would. Being 3D printed, it is very elastic in design meaning you can fit whatever fans you wish to the very open air flow environment, as well as customize you own laptop contact surface to print that way it fits your computer best. Dimensions for contact surface are 410mm X 310mm X 2.5 mm with Filets of 37.25mm Radii.

author: reprat0r

description.text: Use this simple pump to move fluid around in small quantities.  It may require more torque than you expect.

Assemble in three layers from 6mm plywood.  All holes are sized for the metric hardware I had on hand.  Use 608 skate bearings for the pressure rollers; they go in the locations indicated by the green circles in the plans.  I added washers between the layers for spacing.  This was necessary to get rid of unnecessary friction on the bearings because they're a bit more than 6mm thick.
Run the tubing in and out the notch in the bottom, going around the inside of the raceway.  The bearings should smash it completely flat and make a watertight seal inside the tube.
You may have to move the holes on the rotor arms in or out depending on the size of your tubing and bearings.

comments.text: Nice work - How about 3 bearings at 60 degrees?
comments.author: Smoutech

comments.text: I considered that.  My initial prototype actually had only one bearing, because I was trying to use as few parts as possible.  This is for a project that would need about 60 pumps.  The problems inherent in turning that many of these pumps at the same speed are great, to say the least, so we're going in other directions.

This is a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:51156 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=51156

I had some problems with this print. Apparently the height is some mm too much for my replicator, so the tops are smeared. Reduce parameter second_height to avoid this if you build volume height is not 15 cm.
I printed with infill 10%, but that is too low, legs break too easy, so use more infill. The legs start to wobble easily due to the print head as the legs get higher, which reduces how nicely a printer can print this. Use a firmware with accelleration (eg for makerbot firmware 6.2 or 7), and not too high travel speed to reduce vibrations. It is possible to add a ring halfway of the height by using the fifth and sixt ring in the customizer, this would improve shaking during build, but I think it looks less nice :-) Whatever you do, count on a 9 to 10 hours to build this. title: Commodore Vic-20 Cartridge Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Get the feeling I'm choosing the least common machines to make cartridge cases for? Introducing a 3D printable cartridge cases for the Commodore Vic-20 home computer of the early eighties. I'll admit the Vectrex cart I uploaded before is probably a better design, but it works and that's good enough for me. Also, this case is based on the "Raid on Fort Knox" cart you see in the images, ruthlessly ripped apart for the purposes of this project. As with the Vectrex cart, I used Pro/Engineer's now deceased sibling, Pro/Desktop to design the models and have uploaded the ".des" design files. I also put up my measurement notes, again to be given about the same trust as the average politician. While I have the chance, I'll just say that you do have to break some (or at least, the "Raid on Fort Knox") original cartridge case to get into them, despite how co-operative it looks with those screwdriver slots on the bottom. There is a lug inside the right side of the cart that has to be broken. It took me ages looking on the net to be sure of this. Now that I've cleared my two cartridge case backlog, this will probably be my last one for quite a while. Prints pictured were made with a good old Makerbot Cupcake CNC. Long live Cupcakes!

I actually made this model before the Vectrex one I uploaded recently, about a year ago in fact. As a result, I'm half guessing about the details as my memory has well and truly faded.
Anyway, it's mostly obvious. The two halves were too big for my Cupcake's build platform, so I split them into four more manageable pieces, then glued them together using that rather visible hot melt glue. If you have a machine that can print small buildings in a single bound, just use the whole models. I somehow got away without a raft for version one, but must have lost my touch because by version three (thankfully the last) I hadn't a hope of going raftless.
Well once you have the two halves (or perhaps the halves of them) in materialised form, you can print out "Board Rotation Stop" (at the end of the downloads because I almost forgot it). This is my cheat for getting the board stopper where it needs to be to mach the dimensions of the board. Get it in the right spot and glue well while admiring my poor design. I did this because I know there are a lot of board sizes out there, but don't want to destroy all my Vic-20 cartridges to find out what they are. If you have a big board, the flat bit of the stopper should slip under the board to give you more room. Though, really how well it works with big boards is a bit of an unknown for me.
The screw hole should be 3.3mm. My printer swelled it up a bit so I think I used a screw about the same diameter and 10mm long.
Once you're done, do your usual wrestle with the back of your Vic-20 to get the cart in (hence why you should do a good job gluing the board stop), and enjoy the marvels of vintage computing.

For Christmas this year I created chess cookie cutters. Here are the designs, feel free to use them for yourself and if you hurry they can be ready before Christmas morning. I used the Custom-Cookie-Generator ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3433 ) created by Guru to create the 3d designs its loads of help. in the Discussion leave your location country ,state or providence im interested in the distribution globaly of who liked it.

print, clean, use, enjoy
useful hints...
-use a tooth pick to poke the small parts out helpfull on the pawns.
-use a silicone mat or wax paper to keep thin pieces in tact while cooking 
-decorateing to prevent the mess of frosting on fingers. dissolve sugar in as little h2o as possible it will be like syrup then add food coloring and paint it on. The sugar will dry hard which will make it easier to play without making a mess.
new rule you may eat one piece when you are in checkmate and no one is looking

This Bearing post has a bit of a hat on it that can be used to force the belt moving over the Y axis bearing up and away from the belt going around the bearing. I was having issues with the vibration of the belt causing the belt to catch as it went over the bearing.. After using this it has solved my issues and it also actually reduces some of the belt vibration and allows for some belt tensioning as well depending on its rotation.

title: Laser Cut Build Platform for Prusa-Mendel

description.text:
This is a layout for a build platform for a Prusa-Mendel Iteration 2 and is probably suitable for several other designs.
At 220mm square, it is slightly larger than the Heated Bed PCB.

Use the DXF to get a laser cut plate made. Or print it out and use it as a template to cut one out by hand.
The plate is heated by attaching a silicone rubber heater pad to the underside.
Available for sale at http://www.makershop.co.nz/Heaters

description.text:
Maple shaped coasters for your fall holiday dinners.
Coaster Holder can fit up to 10 coasters. https://firstbuild.com/kingrahl/maple-leaf-coasters/

To get the different color veins - Stop print when veins start and change color.
For a non-slip surface - Print in one color and fill between veins with a different color Sugru.
Use vibrant Autumn colors to match your décor.
Stitch marker for crochet. I used to lost all markers i have bought. If you are like me, this project is for you.

I use a lot of these wonderful data capture cards from weedtech.com since they are supported by the home automation system of which I am a developer MacHomeAutomation.com unfortunately they dont have good mounting options. in the past I've just hot glued, or cable tied them in place but this is much better. After attaching to this frame I was able to attach them more securely.
Since these have indentations on the bottom for the nuts that hold them in it was necessary to print them with a raft and support. Otherwise I just printed it 100% infill and 1 extra shell.

author: arod24

description.text:
This is the result of a basic 123D Design lesson I was giving this afternoon. For each aspect we covered, and every question that was asked, was essentially covered in this part in one way or another except for any moves that were "undone".
The part that's shown in the picture that we printed is only 60mm in length versus the original scaled size posted (which I believe was around 0.3% of it's original size). The part was printed on our Form1+ SLA with Spot-A HT clear resin with their transparent green dye added.
AutoDesk 123D Design
